column1: Trait (if possible, try to match ICD9, SNOMED, or Google code sheets)
column6: SNOMED-CT code used by Microsoft Healthvault
column7: Google code used by Google Health data
column8: Notes

In general, ICD codings cover "malignant neoplasm of the X" while SNOMED and CUI have "X carcinoma". The latter is more specific and preferred. For example, "malignant neoplasm of the breast" could refer to a non-breast-cell cancer that happened to start in the breast. (Unfortunately ICD doesn't have the more specific term.)

Cancers chosen mainly from this list of the most common types: http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/types/commoncancers
http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/types/commoncancers
ICD9 "174" is female specific (male code is 175). We go ahead and use it because "female" accounts for 99% of breast cancer.

There are many varieties, so we don't try to break it down. Lymphoma classifications have also changed a lot, ICD-9 has both 200 and 202, both with archaic subcategories. 202 includes "unspecified" and so seems the most appropriate.

We did not ask about "hyperlipidemia" because we ask more specifically about "high cholesterol" and "high blood triglycerides".

We don't ask about overweight / obesity because this trait is highly variable over a lifetime, and we should be more specifically recording height and weight.

ICD-9 doesn't treat hypercholesterolemia and hyperglyceridemia as separately reported. "Pure hypercholesterolemia" (272.0) implies no hyperglyceridemia, and the reverse for "pure hyperglyceridemia" (272.1). "Mixed hyperlipidemia" (272.2) would be the correct encoding for people who have both. ICD-10 has the same issue (E78.0, E78.1, E78.2). 

We go with the same approach Google Health seems to have taken -- "272.0" for high cholesterol and 272.1 for high triglycerides, even when both are occurring together.

column1: Hereditary thrombophilia (includes Factor V Leiden and Prothrombin G20210A)
column8: ICD-9 code 289.81 is an approximation meaning "Primary hypercoagulable state" and includes some different coagulation issues. Unfortunately no better coding exists. ICD-10 has more specific coding.

column1: Chronic tension headaches (15+ days per month, at least 6 months)

column8: ICD-9 code is for "type I", which is what we're probably seen reported in the absence of spina bifida also being reported.

column1: Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (includes Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and HNPP)

column8: Difficult to code in ICD-9, you have to choose between "hereditary & idiopathic" (356) or "toxic & inflammatory" (357). Wikipedia currently points to the first category (suggestions are 356.0 & 356.8) as did Google Health (356.9), so we'll go with that. 356.9 is the "Not otherwise specified" category within 356.
We skip "amblyopia" and "diplopia". The first is generally caused by strabismus (which we ask about), and the latter is more of a symptom than a trait.
In ICD10 H40 and H42 both relate to glaucoma, H40 looks like the most general (H42 is glaucoma when associated with other disease).

column1: Sensorineural hearing loss or congenital deafness

column8: Many of these traits were taken from this site: http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/Arrhythmia/AboutArrhythmia/Conduction-Disorders_UCM_302046_Article.jsp
Actually encoding is for essential hypertension (95% of hypertension cases).
Unfortunately ICD9 encoding can't get this specific.
Unfortunately ICD9 encoding can't get this specific.
ICD-9 coding is just "other premature beats"

column1: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)

column8: ICD10 specifies "recurrent".
Not great coding in ICD9, used a more general category.

column1: Hair loss (includes female and male pattern baldness)

column8: ICD9 coding isn't very good for this ("Other dyschromia")
ICD9 coding isn't very good for this ("Other specified congenital anomalies of iris and ciliary body")
ICD9 coding is very poor ("cleft palate unilateral incomplete")
